statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Damon Stoudamire's jumper with 3.2 seconds remaining lifted the Portland Trail Blazers over the Los Angeles Clippers 80-79 Monday night.
article.headline: Stoudamire strikes at right time
article.linkText: Money Mouse: Stoudamire hits game-winner over Clippers
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Damon Stoudamire had shooting problems all night until Jeff McInnis fouled out. That left diminutive Earl Boykins to guard Stoudamire with the clock running down. Stoudamire's 21-foot jumper with 3.2 seconds remaining lifted Portland over the Los Angeles Clippers 80-79 Monday. It was one of only two field goals in the final seven minutes by the Trail Blazers, who were outscored 30-18 in the fourth quarter. "We had already diagrammed a pick-and-roll play if they didn't score at that point," Stoudamire said. "So I basically was just trying to get to a spot on the floor where I knew I could make a shot. Earl's a smaller defender than McInnis, so I was able to shoot right over him." Quentin Richardson scored 16 points, and Michael Olowokandi had 15 points and 15 rebounds for the Clippers, who have lost 18 of 22 meetings with the Blazers. Stoudamire, who had a season-high 29 points against the Clippers on Jan. 19, missed his first five shots and 11 of 16 overall. But his winning basket gave him 15 points and the Blazers their 13th victory in 18 games. "Great players make great shots," Clippers forward Corey Maggette said. "We really needed this win, and it was tough to lose on a shot like that." The Clippers, whose 57.9 field-goal percentage on Jan. 1 against the Blazers was the highest this season by a Portland opponent, shot only 33 percent this time and were 4-for-16 on 3-pointers. Eric Piatkowski, who scored a career-high 36 points against Dallas on Saturday and played the entire 48 minutes, was 0-for-9 in 21 minutes against the Blazers and was held scoreless for the third time this season. The loss was the fifth in seven games for the Clippers, who slipped two games behind Seattle for the final Western Conference playoff spot. Olowokandi and Elton Brand combined for 30 of the Clippers' 37 rebounds through the first three quarters, but scored only 16 points between them as Portland took a 62-49 lead into the fourth. Richardson, who sat out Saturday because of a sprained left foot, scored seven points during a 16-4 run that turned a 68-57 deficit into a 73-72 lead with 4:34 to play. "They have young, energetic players, so you know they can make a run at any time. And they did," Portland coach Maurice Cheeks said. "But we thought we would make more shots in the fourth quarter." McInnis sank two free throws during the rally after technical fouls against Rasheed Wallace and Cheeks. Wallace, who led the NBA with 41 technicals last season and has 18 this season, was whistled for taunting with seven minutes left. "We've got to learn to stay off the officials because they're going to make their calls no matter what. They're not perfect and we're not perfect," Cheeks said. "But we had our poise late in the game." Wallace's layup regained the lead briefly for the Blazers, before Olowokandi's short jumper and a fast-break layup by McInnis gave the Clippers a 77-74 edge with 2:32 left. McInnis fouled out 25 seconds later, and Stoudamire made both free throws. Boykins missed a last-second driving layup down the left baseline. Darius Miles, one of two Clippers to play in all 54 games, sprained his right shoulder when he went flying over Bonzi Wells on an offensive foul and crashed to the court with 5:16 left in the second quarter. Miles, who finished with 15 points, played another 63 seconds before getting treated and didn't return until 3:18 remained in the third period.

Game notes
The Clippers have beaten 11 teams that have defeated the two-time defending champion Lakers this season -- including the Trail Blazers on New Year's Day. ... Portland activated C Ruben Boumtje Boumtje, who was sidelined 15 games because of a sprained ankle. Fellow rookie Zach Randolph was placed on the injured list after straining his right ankle in the morning shootaround. ... Portland G Steve Kerr, whose mother still lives in nearby Pacific Palisades, shaved off his mini-beard when he got to town. "My mom lives out here, so I couldn't show up there looking like Grizzly Adams," Kerr told Blazers broadcaster Mike Rice during the pregame shootaround.
